channel.title: Nature Communications
channel.description:
Nature Communications is an open access, multidisciplinary journal dedicated to publishing high-quality research in all areas of the biological, health, physical, chemical and Earth sciences. Papers published by the journal aim to represent important advances of significance to specialists within each field.

We are committed to providing an efficient service for both authors and readers. Our team of independent editors make rapid and fair publication decisions. Prompt dissemination of accepted papers to a wide readership and beyond is achieved through a programme of continuous online publication.
channel.dc:rights: © 2025 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Direct observation of the on-site oxygen 2p two-hole Coulomb energy in La2CuO4
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 05 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-65314-w

Electron correlations are important for superconductivity in layered copper oxides. Here, the authors use Auger photoelectron coincidence spectroscopy to directly determine the oxygen 2p hole-hole Coulomb energy in the undoped cuprate La2CuO4.
item.dc:title: Direct observation of the on-site oxygen 2p two-hole Coulomb energy in La2CuO4
item.dc:creator: Danilo Kühn
Swarnshikha Sinha
Fredrik O. L. Johansson
Katarzyna Siewierska
Antonello Tebano
Nils Mårtensson
Andreas Lindblad
Daniele Di Castro
Alexander Föhlisch

item.title: Ten-valley excitonic complexes in charge-tunable monolayer WSe<sub>2</sub>
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 05 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-65731-x

Exotic six- and eight-particle excitonic complexes have recently been observed in 2D semiconductors. Here, the authors uncover a stable many-body exciton in WSe2–comprising 20 interacting quasiparticles–that emerges when strong electrostatic doping fills the Q valley.
item.dc:title: Ten-valley excitonic complexes in charge-tunable monolayer WSe<sub>2</sub>
item.dc:creator: Alain Dijkstra
Amine Ben Mhenni
Dinh Van Tuan
Elif Çetiner
Muriel Schur-Wilkens
Junghwan Kim
Laurin Steiner
Kenji Watanabe
Takashi Taniguchi
Matteo Barbone
Nathan P. Wilson
Hanan Dery
Jonathan J. Finley

item.title: Magnetoactive bistable soft actuators for programmable large shape transformations at low magnetic fields
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 05 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-64855-4

Magnetoactive soft actuators typically require high, continuous magnetic fields for large shape changes. Here, the authors introduce an actuator that employs magnetic bistability to enable fast switching in low-density magnetic fields.
item.dc:title: Magnetoactive bistable soft actuators for programmable large shape transformations at low magnetic fields
item.dc:creator: Hao Wen
Zihao Shao
Yuxuan Sun
Chiyuan Ma
Feihong Xiang
Liangyu Xia
Xinhui Zhu
Xiaoxiang Li
Liang Li
